Neil is upstairs with his wife and daughter, while jamming with Freddy Gruber.
RIP Neil: It was always a privilege watching Rush in concert.

Caught in the camera eye,
I have no heart to lie,
I can't pretend a stranger is a long awaited friend."

snippet.textDisplay:
Rick, thanks for posting this video. You echoed what and how so many of us (younger and not so young) feel about this loss, how Rush was with a lot of us through high school. college, young adulthood and beyond, and how profound of a loss this is. Especially difficult the thought of Neil losing his mental prowess through the horrible illness of brain cancer.

Condolences to his family, Alex and Geddy and to all of us to have been lucky enough to enjoy Rush through the years.

snippet.textDisplay:
It was 1988, I was in the 6th grade. I was at friends house playing games, and his dad had music on. Hand Over Fist came on, and I stopped the game to listen. The sound was so unique and amazing. I was hooked from that moment. In the 30+ years since, I got to see them live 11 times. Each time was truly amazing, and Neil especially, blew everyone away with those solos of his. Highlight of every show.
I wish I would have known the last time was the last time.
RIP Neil.

snippet.textDisplay: I was also very shocked to learn of his passing.  Never even knew he was battling cancer.  But that is Neil's personality to not want people to be sorry for him, or be cast in the spotlight.  The guy was just happy to be behind the drum kit, and the fame and fortune that came with it was just a benefit.  He truly was the most influential percussionist of the last 40+ years, and about every modern rock/metal drummer that we love were built from the foundation that Neil set.  Really the saddest thing to happen in the Rock/Metal era to happen since losing Dimebag Darrell and Vinnie Paul as far as musicians go.  Obviously, losing Chris Cornell and Chester Bennington were huge blows as well.  Fly high Neil!  At least now he can be with his wife and daughter again.

snippet.textDisplay:
Neil's book Ghost Rider got my through some tough times. For me, it's easier to bear pain when you hear about another's pain. If you find yourself grieving, be sure to check out this book as he goes through the process of losing his first wife and daughter finding a reason to live. His other books are great too.
Everyone knows he was a master on the drums that people all over the world aspire to, but many forget about his lyrics he wrote...they are something very special as well.
Prayers to his wife and daughter to overcome this major loss.

snippet.textDisplay:
You have got to feel in some way uplifted... loss is always tough to deal with, but to see so many saddened people up and down the globe, so much love, respect, admiration, so many baffled people feeling like we've lost a family member or a very dear close friend. 
To know that one human being was able to reach such levels of perfection, such excellence and affected so many people for the better... and finally, if it's any consolation, to know he is no longer in any pain or suffering in any way... for me it's my way of finding peace... because it truly feels like the loss of a brother... finally for all his talent and creativity, this will always remain a mantra in my life: "I don't have faith in faith, I don't believe in belief, you can call me faithless, I still cling to hope, and I believe in love, and that's faith enough for me"... Farewell and godspeed, friend.

snippet.textDisplay:
I, personally feel grateful that we were able to be alive and know the majesty that was and always will be RUSH.

Some people laughed at or scoffed us for our musical preference; they didn’t get it. Some never will. That’s okay. WE did... WE were the lucky ones!!

Many of us invested (1980 for me) years of our life with this band, some more some less; but we were nonetheless in their club. RUSH included us... we were RUSH!!

Whether they knew it or not, RUSH has been with all of us through our good days and our bad ones too.

They helped us celebrate our victories and defeats. They were there during famine or feast.

... and WE will always love you and be with you, Closer to our Hearts.

snippet.textDisplay: Back in 1974, I was probably one of the first 500 people in the States to even know who RUSH was.  Played their first record after a friend loaned it to me from elementary school.  We were out on the playground talking about our RUSH, KISS, Zep and Aerosmith records.  We were just punk kids.  Nobody knew who RUSH was except us.  Here we are today, some 45 years later--still celebrating and appreciating the wonders of this band.  Through the years, I have enjoyed playing some of the RUSH songs on bass guitar and drums.  My life would not have been the same without their music.  Those three guys are/were a class act that will never be matched.  Glad to have seen them at three concerts, with my very first concert of any group in 1980--during the Permanent Waves tour.  R.I.P. Neil.  We will always miss and remember you dearly.

snippet.textDisplay: Many kindred spirits showing up around the world when it comes to Neil and Rush in general.   Even more than I would have expected, and so many feeling a real sense of personal loss.   A 40 year drum idol and influencer for me is gone, but will be remembered and enjoyed always through Rush’s timeless and magical music.   The list of my (top tier) drumming idols is sadly getting shorter.   Bonham, Porcaro and now Peart.   May Gadd and Colaiuta live on for many years to come.  Thanks for everything you do, Rick.   Myself, and my 10 year old guitar playing son both love your shows.   I think he’s becoming addicted.   RIP Neil Peart

snippet.textDisplay: Whether or not you liked their music, Rush was always creative, authentic, evolving, and were masters of their respective instruments. Beyond that, in an industry where most bands end up infighting, they exemplified the spirit of a band of best friends who loved each other's company, even after 30 years of working together. Peart's lyrics spoke to a lot of people for good reason, he always felt to me like a voice for the quiet, reflective introverts out there. When I listen to his words I always feel like they just "get" me, and that I'm at home. The fact that they were from my own hometown was the cherry on top of it all. A big loss for sure, but on the other hand Neil has left an incredible, positive mark on the world, which I believe is what he aspired to do with his time on Earth.

snippet.textDisplay: I'm at a loss.  I remember when I was 10 years old and one of the first albums I purchased with my own money was Rush Moving Pictures. When my guitar teacher introduced me to Hemispheres album I was so impressed with that album that I wanted everyone to hear it and would play La Villa Strangiato to my friends.  They were the best and will continue to be into the future.  That's Neils legacy.

snippet.textDisplay: I'll be 57 in March and since before I was a teen I have worshipped this man and this band. Neil has been my idol for over 40 years, so, needless to say, this hit me devastatingly hard. It is the first time I've ever openly wept due to the passing of a rock legend. I'm not ashamed, nor do I care about admitting it. It goes well beyond mere music or idolizing someone. It is personal when if affects so many aspects and eras of your life to such degrees. I've seen an outpouring of emotion online the likes of which I've never seen before from both the music community and fan bases. People who aren't even drummers or musicians have been touched by this musical wizard. I've no doubt that this wound will never quite heal and that, for as long as a lot of we fans live, this will leave a formidable scar. Every time I allow myself to really think about what Neil has meant to me, I break down. He was so very important to me, and I'd surmise to millions of others. The realization and that life simply passes too quickly becomes all the more real when the heroes we grew up with begin passing. This is the end of an era I must to come to grips with even though my heart will not allow my head to wrap itself around the notion that gentle souls must too make the journey. And so I will allow my pain and my tears to be Neil's legacy for this moment. Farewell, Neil Peart. I love you, Sir.

snippet.textDisplay:
Really nice heart felt tribute guys.
I have never met Neil, and I have never even had the opportunity to see Rush live, but I feel such a sense of loss with Neil's passing. He was one of my drumming inspirations and I am still blown away by some of the stuff he came up with on Fly By Night, let alone the body of work that spanned the wonderful career of Rush. His lyrics were so intimate and connected with me on many levels. Neil's integrity, drive, and commitment, set him apart from many of his peers, and Rush as a band have a history of being a pure class act throughout their long journey together. His reputation and musical contributions will live on. Thanks Neil.

snippet.textDisplay: It honestly explained a lot when I heard he’d been battling a Glioblastoma for the last 3 years. Even with modern medical tech, that’s a death sentence, and he made it twice as long as average. I’m not surprised he wanted to keep it private, and there had been nothing at all from him in at least 3 years. I expected to at least see more books from him or activity on his blog, or possibly a new album from Rush (even though it wouldn’t include a tour) but now it makes sense.

snippet.textDisplay: Thank you Rick. I've been crying off and on about this since Friday at lunch time when this appeared on my social media. I thought, or hoped this was just some cruel joke but no, it wasn't.  Like a lot of Rush fans, I grew up with these guys from back in high school and would see them every time they came to California. I will never forget the excitement my buddies and I were experiencing when all of 6 of us first saw them in concert for Moving Pictures. Ever since then we were all hooked, plain and simple!!! Even before that album, I heard Freewill and yes, I was a bit turned off by the singing (at first), but was hooked on this band and their music. Some guy told me, dude, that's Rush!!!!! You should listen to them!! I was like naaahh, and then my brother brough the cassette over and I listed to it and was blown away!!!!  I finally bought Permanent Waves and got into that record, I mean who wouldnt?? To this day, Natural Science is my absolute favorite song and to then I find out the drummer writes all their lyrics?!?!?!?! Wow!!! My childhood friends and I havent seen much of each other in recent years except for an occasional phone call but after I heard this news I managed to get a hold of one of them and told him he was my bro and that I loved him very much. Change is the only constant in the universe and events like this only remind us that nothing lasts forever and to cherish these moments in our life. This sad news really hit home unfortunately. All I can say is Thank God for Rush and these three individuals who helped shape some of my formative years and just helped put a smile on my face. God bless you Neal and THANK YOU for sharing your gift with us...

snippet.textDisplay:
Pretty sure I speak for all Rush fans: it wasn't just about their music and musicianship - it always was about how good people they are in one of those industries that is known for being a meat-grinder and bringing out the worst in people, whether it's Hollywood, music or Washington DC. They didn't just "survive" in a difficult industry, but thrived and went on to become leaders and examples of how it can be done right, and how people can live right. That was always a very special thing about the band Rush that non-fans didn't understand. And that's fine, because if you don't know those special things about them then you won't know why Rush fans are so fanatical. But when people find out about those things, there is no turning back. You become a Rush fan. Oh, and the music is great too.


Rick, thank you for taking the time to make this video. Your speechless manner speaks volumes for all of us.

snippet.textDisplay:
Neil Peart was the single-most influential musician in my life. The intensity and precision he applied to perfecting his craft, made an indelible impression, inspiring me beyond just musical pursuits to many other aspects of life. Neil's departure is felt deeply, by me and the countless other drummers, who were inspired by his extraordinary talent, discipline, and originality. Quoting Kent Hawley's paraphrase from Closer to the Heart, Neil irresistibly "molded hearts" and "forged creativity" that enchanted us to pound along on the nearest surface, note by note, fill by fill, in that thunderous cognizance from which sprung the spirit of Rush. None played the kit with more command and musical flare, imbued with a joyful enthusiasm, a rhythmic iridescence, or a solemn gravitas harmoniously syncopated with his profound lyrical compositions of weight. Neil's signature style effortlessly burst up between musical phrases to mirror Geddy's driving bass melodies here, caress Alex's lead lines there, and fell back again in the steady heartbeat that fueled the co-virtuosity of his bandmates. I am buoyed by the faith that heaven's choirs will be changing time signatures and tempo's (often), awaiting our own entrance to the eternal encore. May his memory resonate in our hearts as vibrantly as his legacy in our lives.

Now, at last I fall before
The Fountain of Lamneth
I thought I would be singing
But I’m tired… out of breath
Many journeys end here
But, the secret’s told the same
Life is just a candle
And a dream must give it flame’
— Neil Peart, "The Fountain of Lamneth"

"Terminat hora diem; terminat auctor opus"
"[as] The hour ends the day; the author ends his work."
– inscribed under "The Necromancer", Caress of Steel, [Christopher Marlowe, Doctor Faustus]

snippet.textDisplay: I’ve seen some negative responses on various channels I have subscribed in response to the emotion conveyed toward Neil’s death. It is what is, right. I lost my mom in 2017. I engulf myself in anything that reminds me of her. I lost my cousin, whom was essentially another brother this past October. I bring up stories to complete strangers as if they knew him. My brother got Moving Pictures for his birthday when he was 13. I was 11. Our tastes in music would never be the same. The way we thought would be different. Both of us guitarists, we dive into the Rush catalog, by record, cassette, and CD. The friends we would make would have the same musical tastes. I joke about how 9th grade was Rush, Zep, The Who, Stones, AC/DC, Floyd...you know the list, but I had no concept of what was on the radio at the time. It was all older rock for us. I can’t think of an old friend without pinning some music to our particular story.  When you pull up next to someone in a car thumping some non-sensical beats and wonder if that person even has a soul...well, you understand. It is difficult to trust someone whom can’t feel the depth of some of this older stuff. Rush, that never stopped once Neil took up the wordsmithing. How many musicians can you name that make you want to read more literary work? Zep with Norse mythology. Tull with...I think they were medieval jesters in a former life! Anyway, I was told in passing by a coworker, “the drummer from rush died, bummer, eh?” What the f? I’ve put more into Rush than I ever cared to put into some of my relatives. It’s painful to see parts of your past die. I appreciate the emotion. I’m there with you, as so many of us are. How lucky we are to have had the chance to get a snippet of Neil’s character and passion. Condolences to all he has touched in his various ways.

snippet.textDisplay: I typically don't have much of an opinion when celebrities pass. They aren't family, friends or acquaintances.  I watch the little news montage and carry on. This is different for me as Rush has always been my favorite band and a huge part of my formative years. They are still in heavy rotation in my playlists and were very fundamental in my desire to learn how to play music. My cousin and I spent countless hours jamming in the basement, listening to Rush and going to see their shows. Neil was an amazing drummer, lyricist and a reluctant rockstar. There will be lots of tributes, montages and reflections on his career, and Neil probably won't care about any of them. He will probably be more concerned about finding good motorcycle roads in whatever the afterlife holds for him.

snippet.textDisplay:
I am the quintessential ZERO ABILITY at music human, but my ear, heart, and passion for it are insanely high. I always had the biggest collections of vinyl, then cassettes, then CDs. Simply put, nothing can move me like music can.
That said, this passing has been the ONLY one amongst musicians that has saddened me to lumps in my throat and watery eyes. We've lost so many but dare I say we've not lost , recently anyways, anyone who is easily and arguably the best at his craft..ever! So much can be said but to keep it succinct let me say, THE Gold Standard of drummers is gone and he will always be that highest standard.

snippet.textDisplay: Thank you, Rick and Jack, I learned this from you last Friday and it made it so much easier to process with you at the “helm” with your warmth, thoughtfulness, and style. You and Jack serve the memory of Rush well. I saw Rush live four times. I lived and loved Moving Pictures as an 11 year old kid in Ponce, Puerto Rico. Their lyrics inspired me to the max. I wouldn’t have wanted to hear the sad news from anyone but both of you. My only regret is that my 12 year old son never got to see him live, but Mr. Peart went on top, and he lives in our memories and echoes of an old applause we can relieve by pressing click on a video in the world wide web.

snippet.textDisplay:
Couldn't watch this at first...I know
what Rick and his colleagues and my fellow subscribers think of NEIL PEART...
I actually heard about it on sports talk radio... everybody it seems has air-drummed to Tom Sawyer at some point in their youthfull exuberance,
and as a guitarist, I'm certainly guilty of that guilty pleasure as well.
Neil was the one of the only drummers besides Bonham who could swing odd-meter that hard, and to see Tool and Dream Theater and others plow that fertile yet intimidating field with such ownership seemed to further validate - if that's even necessary - Neil and Rush's purposeful stewardship of their incredible time in modern music...NEIL PEART is gone, but not soon, if ever, truly forgotten. And has a true master of anything EVER been so humble? And despite the narrow minded asides by journalists regarding Neil's subtle fascination with writings of ayn rand, which fueled some of the flights of fancy of 2112, the ultimate lock yourself in a room with headphones album-
He was a master builder, and master craftsman and a true renaissance man of our time, pushing and pushing and striving, always questioning.
Goodnight sweet prince
